docs.text: Trigonometry Trigonometry Functions $$ \begin{flalign} Sinus =\frac{Opposed}{Hypotenuse} & \;\;\;\; Cosinus =\frac{Adjacent}{Hypotenuse} & \;\;\;\; Tangeant =\frac{Opposed}{Adjacent} \\\\\\ Cosecant =\frac{Hypotenuse}{Opposed} & \;\;\;\; Secant =\frac{Hypotenuse}{Adjacent} & \; Cotangeant =\frac{Adjacent}{Opposed} \end{flalign} $$
docs.title: Trigonometry

docs.text: $$ \begin{flalign} Sinus =\frac{Opposed}{Hypotenuse} & \;\;\;\; Cosinus =\frac{Adjacent}{Hypotenuse} & \;\;\;\; Tangeant =\frac{Opposed}{Adjacent} \\\\\\ Cosecant =\frac{Hypotenuse}{Opposed} & \;\;\;\; Secant =\frac{Hypotenuse}{Adjacent} & \; Cotangeant =\frac{Adjacent}{Opposed} \end{flalign} $$

docs.text: One Matrice Gauss-Jordan elimination Pull scalars Swap out a 0 First row pivot Zero out the column Repeat 2-5 Number of solutions to the linear system One solution \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 & 0 & | & a\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & | & b\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & | & c \end{array}\right] \] No Solutions \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 & 0 & | & a\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & | & b\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & | & c \end{array}\right] \] Many Solutions \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 & 0 & | & a\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & | & b\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & | & 0 \end{array}\right] \]

docs.text: Two Matrices Matrix Operations Matrix Addition \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & -4 \end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 6 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 6 \\ 2 & -2 \end{array}\right] \] Matrix Substraction \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & -4 \end{array}\right] - \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 6 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -6 \\ 2 & -6 \end{array}\right] \] Matrix Multiplication Commutative AB !== BA Associative (AB)C = A(BC) Distributive (A+B)C = AC + BC && C(A+B) = CA + CB 2(0) + 3(0) = 0 2(1) + 3(-1) = -1 -1(0) + 0(0) = 0 -1(1) + 0(-1) = -1 \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & -1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] \] Scalars Scalar Multiplication \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array}\right] → 2 \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 4 & 6 \\ 0 & 2 & 2 \end{array}\right] \] Scalar Division \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 4 & 6 \\ 0 & 2 & 2 \end{array}\right] → \frac{1}{2} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 4 & 6 \\ 0 & 2 & 2 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array}\right] \] Zero Matrices \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] OR \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \] Sources
docs.title: Two Matrices

docs.text: Commutative AB !== BA Associative (AB)C = A(BC) Distributive (A+B)C = AC + BC && C(A+B) = CA + CB 2(0) + 3(0) = 0 2(1) + 3(-1) = -1 -1(0) + 0(0) = 0 -1(1) + 0(-1) = -1 \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & -1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] \]
docs.title: Matrix Multiplication

docs.text: Vectors Properties Direction Magnitude (length) Vector Operations Vector Addition \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 \\ -6 \end{array}\right] \] Vector Substraction \[ \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{cc} -4 \\ -2 \end{array}\right] \] Vector Multiplication $$ \begin{align} \overrightarrow{A} = (-1,2)\\ \overrightarrow{B} = (3,4) \\ \overrightarrow{A} \cdot \overrightarrow{B} = (-1)(3)+(2)(4) \\ = -3 + 8 \\ = 5 \end{align} $$ $$ \begin{align} AB= \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 2 \end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 \\ 4\\ \end{array}\right] = (-1)(3)+(2)(4) \\ = -3 + 8 \\ = 5 \end{align} $$ Dot Product Dot products measures similarities Sources
docs.title: Vectors

docs.text: Calculus 2 Integrals \[ f(x) = \int\limits_a^x f(t) dt \] Plug x in for t \[ f(x) = \int\limits_x^a f(t) dt \] Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug x in for t. \[ f(x) = \int\limits_a^{g(x)} f(t) dt \] Plug g(x) in for t, then multiply by dg | dx \[ f(x) = \int\limits_{g(x)}^{a} f(t) dt \] Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug(x) in for t and multiply by dg | dx. \[ f(x) = \int\limits_{g(x)}^{h(x)} f(t) dt \] Split the limits of integration. Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug g(x) and h(x) in for t, multplying by dg|dx and dh/dx respectively
docs.title: Calculus 2

docs.text: \[ f(x) = \int\limits_a^x f(t) dt \] Plug x in for t \[ f(x) = \int\limits_x^a f(t) dt \] Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug x in for t. \[ f(x) = \int\limits_a^{g(x)} f(t) dt \] Plug g(x) in for t, then multiply by dg | dx \[ f(x) = \int\limits_{g(x)}^{a} f(t) dt \] Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug(x) in for t and multiply by dg | dx. \[ f(x) = \int\limits_{g(x)}^{h(x)} f(t) dt \] Split the limits of integration. Reverse limits of integration and multiply by -1, then plug g(x) and h(x) in for t, multplying by dg|dx and dh/dx respectively
